intro: Phlojodicarpus baicalensis var. arenarius, commonly known as the sand dune lichen, is a unique lichen species that thrives in arid and sandy environments. It belongs to the family Lecanoraceae and is characterized by its crustose growth form, forming a thin, adherent layer on rock surfaces. The thallus is typically pale yellow to orange in color, and it contains a variety of secondary metabolites, including usnic acid and other depsidones. This lichen is often found in coastal and inland desert regions, where it plays a role in soil stabilization and nutrient cycling. Its ability to survive in harsh conditions makes it an important indicator of environmental stress and ecological resilience.
